versions.title: AI Pathfinding Game
versions.vignette: A turn-based game demonstrating AI pathfinding algorithms.
versions.description: A turn-based strategy game made during my Artificial Intelligence in Games module at NYP (Game Development & Technology). The project was mainly for learning pathfinding and finite state machines, and was built in C++ using a custom engine provided by the school.
what_i_did: Implemented A* and BFS pathfinding for AI unit navigation.
Built a finite state machine to manage AI behavior states.
Added a fog-of-war vision system to limit player visibility.
Created a procedural maze generator for randomized maps.
Integrated IrrKlang for sound effects and audio feedback.

versions.title: Bird Laser Targeter on the Edge
versions.vignette: A Raspberry Pi Zero 2W-based bird detection and deterrence system.
versions.description: A Raspberry Pi Zero 2W project that detects birds and deters them using a laser pointer, combining camera input, audio triggers, servos, and a simple control state machine. It supports both on-device and remote detection by sending data over MQTT. My role focused on system integration, hardware interfacing, and overall architecture, while teammates handled model training and the YOLO implementation
what_i_did: Integrated the Raspberry Pi hardware stack (camera, servos, laser diode, and audio trigger input).
Built the control flow as a state machine to coordinate detection and targeting behavior.
Implemented MQTT messaging to support remote/offloaded detection and device-server communication.
Assembled the end-to-end system so detection, targeting, and actuation worked together reliably.

versions.title: Anime Image Upscaler
versions.vignette: An ESRGAN-based image upscaler fine-tuned for anime-style images.
versions.description: An anime image upscaler built using ESRGAN and fine-tuned for anime-style images at 256x256 resolution. The model was trained on a dataset of 15,000+ images to reduce common upscaling artifacts and improve detail when enlarging low-resolution anime artwork. The project also includes a simple Streamlit interface for running upscales interactively.
what_i_did: Prepared and curated a 15,000+ image dataset for anime-style ESRGAN fine-tuning.
Ran ESRGAN fine-tuning experiments and adjusted training settings to improve output quality.
Built a Streamlit UI to upload images and preview upscaled results.

versions.title: Electronica
versions.vignette: A Geometry Wars-inspired top-down shooter built in Unity.
versions.description: A top-down shooter inspired by Geometry Wars, built in Unity. This was a solo project and the final game I worked on at NYP before graduating, so I treated it as a capstone piece and put serious effort into making something I'd be proud of. All gameplay code was written by me over roughly three months.
what_i_did: Built the full game in Unity (C#) as a solo project over three months.
Implemented five enemy behavior types to vary combat patterns and difficulty.
Designed and programmed four boss fights with distinct mechanics and phases.
Created two playable modes (Classic and Onslaught).
Designed and animated the in-game UI, including player and boss health bars.

versions.title: Japanese Learning Card Game
versions.vignette: A digital card game built in Unity around Japanese language learning.
versions.description: A digital card game built in Unity around Japanese language learning. This started as a university design thinking assignment where we were supposed to create a physical board game, but I convinced my group to build a digital game instead since it was faster and cheaper to prototype. I implemented the game from scratch in Unity and handled the programming work.
what_i_did: Implemented the full game in Unity (C#) completely on my own.
Built an object-oriented card system to define card data, effects, and behaviors.
Implemented turn flow, deck/hand management, and win/loss conditions.

versions.title: The Last Survivor
versions.vignette: A wave-based top-down shooter built in Unity.
versions.description: A wave-based top-down shooter built in Unity as a Year 2 studio project at NYP. The game was developed by a team of four students and focuses on surviving progressively harder waves with different enemy types and attack patterns.
what_i_did: Implemented the wave progression and enemy spawning system in Unity (C#).
Built enemy movement and pathfinding logic without relying on Unity's NavMesh.
Programmed multiple enemy/NPC types with different behaviors (melee, ranged, turret, and boss).

versions.title: L.O.C.U.S
versions.vignette: A virtual reality horror puzzle game for the HTC Vive.
versions.description: A VR horror puzzle game built for the HTC Vive in Unity. This was a final-year project where I worked with art students, continuing from a prototype started by another student group in the previous semester. The game focuses on motion-based interactions, environmental puzzles, and scripted horror events in a first-person VR setting.
what_i_did: Took over an existing project codebase and continued development from a previous trimester team.
Implemented HTC Vive controller input and interaction logic in Unity (C#).
Built and refined core gameplay systems including puzzles, scripted events, and progression flow.
Integrated gameplay with art assets and level content produced by the art team.

versions.title: Simple Physics Game
versions.vignette: A Peggle-inspired physics game built in C++.
versions.description: A Peggle-inspired physics game made during my Physics for Game Programing module. The project was built in C++ using a custom school-provided engine, mwith a focus on applying basic physics concepts to gameplay.
what_i_did: Implemented basic physics simulation (gravity and impulse forces) for moving objects.
Built custom collision detection and response using vector math.
Integrated IrrKlang for sound effects and audio playback.

versions.title: Resource Management Game
versions.vignette: A real-time resource management simulation built in Java using LibGDX.
versions.description: A real-time resource management simulation built in Java using LibGDX. This project focused on implementing a small game loop with structured game objects, basic UI, and scene management for switching between gameplay and menu screens.
what_i_did: Designed object-oriented game object classes in Java to support core game mechanics.
Implemented scene flow (menus and gameplay) including transitions and UI rendering in LibGDX.

versions.title: Spending Dashboard
versions.vignette: A PySide6 desktop application for tracking and analyzing personal spending data.
versions.description: A PySide6 (Qt) desktop application for tracking, analyzing, and visualizing personal spending data. I moved from a Streamlit dashboard to PySide6 because I wanted to build the same kind of tool without a web-based frontend. The app loads purchase records from a structured .xlsx file, supports filtering and plotting, and includes utilities for maintaining and backing up the data. It includes a dashboard view, a sortable table view, and Excel file automation powered by openpyxl in an offline desktop workflow.
what_i_did: Built a multi-page PySide6 desktop app (dashboard + table view).
Automated Excel validation, formatting, and backups with openpyxl.
Added interactive charts for trends and category breakdowns.

versions.title: Spending Dashboard
versions.vignette: A Streamlit app for tracking and analyzing personal spending data.
versions.description: A Streamlit dashboard for tracking, visualizing, and analyzing personal spending data. It reads purchase records from a structured Excel (.xlsx) file, supports interactive filtering and search, and presents trends through charts and summary views. The project also includes an Excel auto-formatting pipeline to keep data entry consistent and easier to maintain over time.
what_i_did: Built a Streamlit dashboard for browsing and searching spending records.
Added interactive filters for date, cost, and category.
Created Plotly charts for trends and breakdowns.
Automated Excel formatting and conditional styling with openpyxl.

versions.title: Translator Helper
versions.vignette: An AI-powered tool to assist with transcribing and translating anime drama CDs using LLMs and Whisper.
versions.description: Translator Helper is an application that speeds up the process of transcribing and translating anime drama CDs using OpenAI’s API and Whisper. It can generate a first-draft transcription and translation for an entire audio file, export the results into subtitle formats for review, and provide smaller tools for handling individual lines or short audio snippets when needed.
what_i_did: Generated first-draft translations for entire subtitle files to speed up review and editing.
Used Whisper to transcribe full audio files and short snippets when lines were unclear.
Collected translation context by parsing .srt/.ass files and pulling supporting web info.
Provided a grading view to evaluate translations for accuracy, fluency, and cultural fit.

versions.title: Translator Helper
versions.vignette: An AI-powered tool to assist with transcribing and translating anime drama CDs using LLMs and Whisper.
versions.description: A personal tool for helping with transcribing and translating anime drama CDs using LLMs and Whisper. I made it because there are times when I can’t clearly catch a line or I’m unsure how to phrase a translation, so the app helps by generating transcripts, organizing context, and producing translation outputs in a few styles to compare.
what_i_did: Built a translation view that outputs natural, literal, and annotated versions.
Added transcription from audio files or microphone input using Whisper.
Added context support by parsing subtitle files and pulling supporting web info.
Built a grading view to review translations for fluency, accuracy, and cultural fit.

versions.title: Budgeting Spreadsheet Automation
versions.vignette: A Python tool to automate the yearly setup of budgeting spreadsheets.
versions.description: A Python tool that automates the yearly setup of my budgeting spreadsheets by generating new sheets, inserting formulas, and applying formatting automatically. It keeps calculations consistent and improves readability with conditional formatting. This was later replaced by my Spending Dashboard project.
what_i_did: Automated yearly sheet creation, formula insertion, and formatting in Excel with Python.
Added conditional formatting rules to keep categories and totals readable.
Built a small Tkinter GUI to run the setup without editing code.

versions.title: Diamond City Radio (Fallout-Inspired Music Player)
versions.vignette: A Java-based music player inspired by Fallout 4's Diamond City Radio.
versions.description: A Java-based music player inspired by Fallout 4's Diamond City Radio. It plays a mix of music tracks and DJ voice clips, inserting commentary between songs to recreate the feel of an in-game radio station.
what_i_did: Built the app in LibGDX (Java), including the UI and playback controls.
Implemented audio loading and management for music tracks and voice clips.
Created the radio-style playback flow that interleaves DJ commentary between songs.

versions.title: Personal Portfolio Website
versions.vignette: A portfolio website built on Flutter.
versions.description:
Built with Flutter (Web) and deployed with Docker on Google Cloud, this is my personal portfolio site for hosting and organizing my work online. I moved from a Streamlit version to Flutter because Streamlit felt limiting for responsive layouts, and Flutter gave me better control over how the site adapts across desktop and mobile screens. 

After getting the first Flutter version working end-to-end, I iterated on it to improve the UI and make the site feel more finished. During that update, I also expanded the project data model to support multiple versions per project, so the portfolio can reflect how projects evolve over time.

Project content is stored in structured JSON files and rendered into consistent project entries at runtime, so updates are mainly done by editing metadata. The goal was a serviceable, easy-to-update portfolio that presents my work clearly.
what_i_did: Built a Flutter Web portfolio with responsive layouts for desktop and mobile.
Structured project and page content as JSON for data-driven rendering.
Implemented multi-version project entries to track changes over time.
Packaged the site with Docker for consistent deployment.
Hosted the deployed site on Google Cloud.

versions.title: Personal Portfolio Website
versions.vignette: A portfolio website built on Flutter.
versions.description:
Built with Flutter (Web) and deployed with Docker on Google Cloud, this is my personal portfolio site for hosting and organizing my work online. I moved from a Streamlit version to Flutter because Streamlit felt limiting for responsive layouts, and Flutter gave me better control over how the site adapts across desktop and mobile screens.  

Project content is stored in structured JSON files and rendered into consistent project entries at runtime, so updates are mainly done by editing metadata. The goal was a serviceable, easy-to-update portfolio that presents my work clearly.
what_i_did: Built a Flutter Web portfolio with responsive layouts for desktop and mobile.
Structured project and page content as JSON for data-driven rendering.
Packaged the site with Docker for consistent deployment.
Hosted the deployed site on Google Cloud.

versions.title: Personal Portfolio Website
versions.vignette: A portfolio website built with Streamlit and Python.
versions.description: A personal portfolio site built with Python + Streamlit to get a simple web presence up quickly without needing much frontend work. The site's content (projects and pages) is stored in a JSON file, and each page is generated from that data so I can update the portfolio by editing entries rather than rewriting the UI. It's deployed on Google Cloud in a Docker container.
what_i_did: Built the portfolio site in Streamlit with a simple multi-page layout.
Implemented tag and category filtering for browsing projects.
Set up Docker-based deployment on Google Cloud for hosting and updates.
Implemented a ProjectObject-based renderer to generate pages from structured project metadata.

versions.title: YouTube Comment Keyword Search
versions.vignette: A Python project that analyzes YouTube comments for keyword and sentiment trends.
versions.description: A Python project that pulls video and comment data from my YouTube channel using the YouTube Data API, then runs keyword and sentiment analysis to see what topics show up most often. It generates separate word clouds for positive and negative comments to visualize common terms, mainly as a small experiment in sentiment analysis and basic text visualization.
what_i_did: Pulled video and comment data from the YouTube Data API and cleaned it for analysis.
Implemented sentiment scoring over comments to separate positive vs negative text.
Generated word clouds and simple plots to visualize common keywords by sentiment.
